page.title: 09CHART SUTTON
page.content: Most of this small village sits on top of the Greensand ridge overlooking the Weald of Kent to the south, though there are some houses down the slope. The older dwellings tend to be timber-framed and weather-boarded. There are some private houses around little closes, and also a large area of council houses on the west of the village. A few of the latter are examples of the post-war pre-fabricated Airey houses which were not supposed to last for long, but people are still living in them. The village is well looked after and the gardens pretty. There is a Post Office which is also a general store, a pub called the 'Buffalo', and an off-licence. Nearby, to the west, is a large house called Amberfield which stands adjacent to the old Rochester to Hastings Roman road.
